The main problems of liquid-phase oxidation of methylarenes to benzaldehydes are that the catalytic reaction rate is slow, benzaldehydes are easily over-oxidized to form benzoic acids, and a large amount of solvent is required. These problems make it difficult to realize the liquid phase catalytic oxidation of methylarenes to benzaldehydes in industrial production. Here, we report the catalytic oxidation of toluene to form benzaldehyde, by using N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) as the radical catalyst, sheet-like Co-Mn-Al oxides (CMA-n) as the redox catalyst, and 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexafluoropropan-2-ol (HFIP) as the solvent. CMA-n/NHPI was found to be highly active in catalyzing the oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. The use of HFIP as the solvent prevents the over-oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. In addition, the reaction proceeded at a high concentration of toluene. The conversion rate of toluene reached 5826 μmol g−1 h−1, and the generation rate of benzaldehyde reached 4049 μmol g−1 h−1. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Co-precipitation method Hydrotalcite Co-Mn-Al oxides Toluene Liquid phase catalytic oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Selective oxidation of aromatic methyl groups to aldehydes is a critical and challenging topic in fundamental and industrial research. Firstly, due to the relatively higher aromatic C-H bond dissociation energy compared with aromatic C-X (X = Cl, Br or I) bonds, it is more difficult to break the aromatic C-H band than the aromatic C-X bond [1]. Secondly, aromatic aldehydes are easily over-oxidized to aromatic acids. Preventing the formation of aromatic acids is a critical problem that must be solved [2,3]. Benzaldehyde is the simplest aromatic aldehyde and is widely used in chemical, medical, food, cosmetics, and other industries [4,5]. The industry's primary methods for preparing benzaldehyde are chlorination, gas-phase oxidation, and liquid-phase oxidation. The chlorinated oxidation method is prevalent in developing countries. The method generates a large amount of chlorine-containing waste, and the resulting product contains chlorine, making it unsuitable for use in medical, food, and other fields [6,7]. Gas-phase oxidation can be operated continuously without the need for the separation of products and catalysts. However, the reaction temperature is usually high, and a significant amount of benzyl benzoate and benzoic acid side products are formed. Furthermore, a fraction of the toluene is decomposed to form COx [8–11]. Benzaldehyde is easily oxidized to benzoic acid, so it is necessary to find an effective solvent to prevent over-oxidation [12]. Therefore, for the catalytic oxidation of toluene in the liquid phase, the main goal is to find an effective catalyst and a solvent that can avoid the over-oxidation of benzaldehyde. Recently, more and more publications have reported the photocatalytic production of benzaldehyde from toluene. The main reason is the high photocatalytic selectivity to benzaldehyde. The methyl group on toluene (C6H5CH3) is oxidized to the corresponding cation radical (C6H5CH2·) by the hole at the photocatalyst surface. At the same time, O2 molecules, which are electron acceptors, are converted into reactive oxygen species (·O2 –) by accepting electrons from the photocatalyst surface. C6H5CH2· is then oxidized by ·O2 – to give benzaldehyde [13–18]. The photocatalytic solvent-free reactions have been reported in some articles but it is challenging to apply the trace photocatalytic conversion of toluene to industrial processes [14,15,18–20]. Many publications report solvent-containing liquid phase photocatalytic oxidation of toluene, some of these approaches achieve both high toluene conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity [13,21–23]. For example, Cao's group reported that p-BWO nanosheets exhibited strong oxidation towards C(sp3)-H bonds under visible light radiation. The conversion rate of toluene can reach 4388 μmol g−1 h−1 [13]. However, high conversion of toluene was obtained using much higher amounts of solvent than toluene, for example, ∼0.11 mL toluene with 3 mL acetonitrile. Moreover, the yield of benzoic acid exceeded 65% after 24 h of reaction. Cao's group revealed that increasing the ratio of toluene to solvent accelerates the conversion. However, it is unclear whether increasing the amount of toluene will affect the selectivity to benzaldehyde [13]. Ishii's group developed the selective oxidation of benzyl C-H bonds to carboxylic acid using N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) with Co2+/3+ or Mn2+/3+ salts under an O2 environment [24–27]. NHPI loses a hydrogen atom to form the intermediate phthalimide-N-oxyl (PINO) during the reaction process. PINO extracts hydrogen from the benzyl group and returns it to NHPI, and the benzyl group is thereby activated to form (C6H5CH2·) [25,28]. Benzaldehyde is an intermediate in this system and is rapidly over-oxidized to benzoic acid under the O2 environment [28]. In order to prevent over-oxidation, Pappo's group used 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexafluoropropan-2-ol (HFIP) as a solvent for the oxidation of methylarenes to aldehyde [28]. They proposed that the aldehyde group of benzaldehyde and the hydroxyl group of HFIP formed an H-bond adduct, which significantly slowed down the further oxidation of the aldehyde group [28]. Using an NHPI/Co(OAc)2 co-catalyst with HFIP as the solvent, the conversion and selectivity of toluene within 4 h reached 91% and 90%, respectively [28]. To our knowledge, this catalytic system's oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde is much more efficient than that of the currently reported photocatalysts. However, the separation and recovery of homogeneous NHPI-Co(OAc)2 catalysts is difficult. Due to the presence of the catalyst, benzaldehyde may be easily over-oxidized when the solvent is separated by distillation. Furthermore, this catalytic system uses excess expensive HFIP solvent (∼26 μL toluene, 500 μL HFIP). It is not known whether reducing the use of HFIP would affect the selectivity to benzaldehyde. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are generally regarded as promising catalysts because of their two-dimensional sheet-like structure, thermal stability, high surface area and adjustable surface basicity [29–31]. The general formula of LDHs is [ M 1 − x 2 + M x 3 + OH 2 ] x + [ A x / n n − ] x − · m H 2 O . An- is an interlayer anion such as CO3 2- or NO3 -. M2+ and M3+ are divalent and trivalent cations, respectively [24,29–32]. Different metal ions, such as Co or Mn, can be incorporated into the LDH structure. Highly dispersed metal oxides are obtained by calcination of LDHs. To the best of our knowledge, only a few papers have reported the catalytic oxidation of methylarenes to benzaldehydes using calcined LDHs. Zhou's group reported the liquid phase catalytic oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde by calcined Co-Al LDHs. The toluene conversion was low (8.2%), even with excess solvent (∼0.58 mL toluene, 10 mL acetonitrile) [33]. Wu and co-workers investigated Mg-Al LDHs modified by different metal cations and their calcined metal oxides. They found that Ti3+-modified Mg3Al-LDH gave high benzaldehyde selectivity (97.5%), but the toluene conversion was low (8.7%) without solvent. In addition, their reaction required high temperature (150 °C) and high pressure (1 MPa) conditions, which put higher requirements on industrial equipments [30]. In this work, the catalytic oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde was studied using HFIP as the solvent, NHPI as the radical catalyst, and Co-Mn-Al oxides calcined from Co-Mn-Al LDHs precursors as the redox metal catalyst. The effects of different proportions of Co-Mn-Al metal oxides and HFIP dosage on the liquid-phase catalytic oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde were investigated. In addition, the reusability and stability of the catalyst were also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Co-Mn-Al LDHs were prepared by a co-precipitation method, and five samples were synthesized with different Co-Mn contents (Co4−xMnxAl, x = 0; 1; 2; 3; 4). Typically, solution A was prepared by dissolving a total of 0.08 mol Co-Mn nitrates (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O and Mn(NO3)2·4 H2O), and 0.02 mol Al(NO3)3·9 H2O in 120 mL deionized water; solution B was prepared by dissolving 0.067 mol Na2CO3 and 0.2 mol NaOH in 120 mL deionized water. Then, solution A and solution B were added dropwise to a four-necked flask. The reaction temperature was maintained at 60 °C using a magneto stirring water bath with vigorous stirring. During the dropwise addition, the pH was set at 8.5 ± 0.5. After solution A was added, the pH was controlled to 9 ± 0.5 by controlling the amount of solution B. Then, the mixed solution was heated to 80 °C, vigorously stirred, and aged for 24 h. The resulting precipitate was filtered and washed 3 times with deionized water. The filtered precipitate was dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h. The obtained hydrotalcite catalyst precursors are denoted as CMA-n LDHs, where n = 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 for Co4Al, Co3MnAl, Co2Mn2Al, CoMn3Al and Mn4Al, respectively. The calcination treatment of the CMA-n LDHs was carried out at 400 ℃ for 4 h to obtain the corresponding mixed oxides. The obtained Co-Mn-Al oxides are denoted as CMA-n (n = 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5). 2.2 Characterization of catalysts X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured by an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker AXS, D8 Advance) with a Cu Kα radiation source. The microstructures of CMA-n LDHs and CMA-n were obtained by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (Zeiss, SIGMA HD) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEOL JEM-2100EX). The specific surface areas of the samples were determined from the N2 adsorption isotherms obtained using a Beishide BSD-PS2 instrument. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (ESCALAB 250Xi, Al Kα) was used to determine the oxidation states of elements using the catalyst surface. Reactants and products were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Fuli GC9720 Plus) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). 2.3 Catalytic oxidation of toluene The catalytic oxidation of toluene was carried out in a 100 mL glass three-neck flask (a photo of the entire reaction device is shown in Fig. S1). A magneto stirring oil bath was used to heat and stir: the heating temperature was 50 ℃ and the stirring speed was about 865 rpm. The amount of HFIP was 20 mL, and a 42 L oxygen bag was used to provide O2. A peristaltic pump (BT100–2 J, pump head YZ15B; speed range: 0.1–150 rpm; speed accuracy: 0.1 rpm) was introduced to perform the internal circulation of oxygen so that bubbles were continuously generated in the reaction system. The peristaltic pump tube was a 25# fluorine rubber tube (MasterFlex, 4.8 *8.0 mm), and the flow adjustment range was 0.18–270.9 mL/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CMA-n precursors Fig. S2 shows the XRD patterns of CMA-n LDHs before calcination. The XRD pattern of CMA-1 LDH in Fig. S2 shows the crystal structure of Co-Al hydrotalcite (JCPDS 51–0045). When the Mn element replaces a fraction of Co (CMA-2 LDH, CMA-3 LDH, and CMA-4 LDH), the characteristic (003), (006) and (012) peaks of Co-Al hydrotalcite still exist, indicating that Mn does not destroy the Co-Al hydrotalcite structure [33]. Nevertheless, characteristic peaks of MnCO3 (JCPDS 44–1472) also appear in the XRD patterns of CMA-2 LDH, CMA-3 LDH, and CMA-4 LDH, and the peak intensities of MnCO3 increase with the increase in Mn content [34]. When all of the Co is replaced by Mn (CMA-5 LDH), the hydrotalcite structure disappears, and only the MnCO3 (rhodochrosite) structure (JCPDS 44–1472) is seen. Fig. S3 shows SEM images of the CMA-n precursors. CMA-1 LDH and CMA-2 LDH have apparent hydrotalcite layer structures; when the Mn content is gradually increased (CMA-2 LDH to CMA-4 LDH), the hydrotalcite layered structure seems to be gradually disappearing. When Co is entirely replaced by Mn (CMA-5 LDH), the layered structure is no longer visible in the SEM image [35]. These results are consistent with the evolution of the XRD patterns described above (Fig. S2). 3.2 Characterization of CMA-n oxides Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the products (CMA-1, CMA-2, CMA-3, CMA-4, and CMA-5) obtained by calcination of the CMA-n LDHs at 400 ℃ for 4 h. All the calcined samples show no characteristic XRD peaks of LDHs. The crystallinity of metal oxides varies from CMA-1 to CMA-5. CMA-5 has the highest crystallinity, and it displays apparent characteristic XRD peaks of alumina (JCPDS 51–0769) and manganese oxide (JCPDS 18–0803). CMA-1 displays characteristic XRD peaks of cobalt oxide (JCPDS 43–1003) but no characteristic XRD peaks of alumina, indicating that alumina in CMA-1 is amorphous. CMA-4 has all the characteristic XRD peaks of alumina, cobalt oxide and manganese oxide, but it has the lowest crystallinity among these samples. SEM images of CMA-1, CMA-2, CMA-3, CMA-4, and CMA-5 are shown in Fig. 2. According to the SEM images, the Co-Mn-Al oxides (CMA-1, CMA-2, CMA-3 and CMA-4) obtained by calcination of the CMA-n LDHs at 400 ℃ for 4 h have an apparent layered structure. Thus, the layered structure of the CMA-n LDHs was preserved in the CMA-1, CMA-2, CMA-3 and CMA-4 after calcination. However, CMA-5 does not have a layered structure since its precursor (rhodochrosite MnCO3) is not a hydrotalcite structure (Fig. S2). TEM measurements were used to further explore the layered structures of the Co-Mn-Al oxide catalysts ( Fig. 3). The CMA-1 to CMA-4 catalysts are predominantly 2D sheet-like structures, while some nanosheets of CMA-1 and CMA-3 stand vertically. The measured thicknesses of the vertically oriented nanosheets range from 4.6 to 8.8 nm. The morphology of CMA-5 is significantly different from the sheet-like structures of CMA-1–4. Fig. S4 presents N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for CMA-1, CMA-2, CMA-3, CMA-4, and CMA-5. The adsorption-desorption isotherms of the different catalysts are similar in type. The calculated specific surface areas of CMA-1, CMA-2, CMA-3, CMA-4, and CMA-5 are 94.7 m2/g, 71.0 m2/g, 67.9 m2/g, 126.6 m2/g, and 49.2 m2/g, respectively. The specific surface areas of the catalysts with sheet-like structures (CMA-1 to CMA-4) are significantly higher than that of CMA-5. CMA-4 has the largest specific surface area, about 2.6 times that of CMA-5. XPS was used to analyze the surface elements’ oxidation states of the CMA-4 catalyst. Fig. 4 displays Mn 2p, Co 2p, Al 2p, and O 1 s spectra. The Mn 2p3/2 region of the Mn 2p spectrum can be divided into two characteristic peaks at 641.9 eV and 644.6 eV, corresponding to Mn3+ and Mn4+ [36–38]. The Mn 2p peak positions for CMA-3 are similar to those of CMA-4. However, the binding energies of Mn3+ (641.5 eV) and Mn4+ (643.7 eV) for the CMA-5 catalyst are lower than those of CMA-3 and CMA-4 (Fig. S5). The fitted peaks of CMA-4 at 780.4 eV and 782.0 eV are attributed to Co3+ and Co2+, respectively [39–41]. Furthermore, the shake-up satellite peaks at 784.4 and 788.4 eV are characteristic of Co2+, due to the presence of unpaired electrons in the valence orbitals of Co2+ [39,41,42]. The single peak in the Al 2p spectrum of CMA-4 (73.8 eV) is attributed to Al3+ [43]. The O 1 s spectrum of CMA-4 can be fitted into four characteristic peaks. The two peaks at the binding energies of 529.6 eV and 530.4 eV correspond to lattice oxygen (O2-). The peak at the binding energy of 531.7 eV can be attributed to metal oxide defects or surface adsorbed oxygen (O-) [34,44–46]. The peak with the highest binding energy (532.9 eV) is attributed to hydroxyl groups, which is most likely due to moisture adsorption by the air-exposed CMA-4 [44–47]. 3.3 Catalytic performance Data for the liquid-phase catalytic oxidation of toluene using different CMA-n catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. Based on the conversion rate of toluene within 20 h, the activity of catalysts is ranked as CMA-4 > CMA-2 = CMA-3 > CMA-5 > CMA-1. The results show that catalysts with different Co-Mn ratios have different catalytic activities. The catalytic oxidation activity of ternary Co-Mn-Al oxides (CMA-2 to CMA-4) is higher than that of binary Co-Al oxides (CMA-1) and Mn-Al oxides (CMA-5). CMA-4 performed best among all the catalysts regarding toluene conversion and benzaldehyde selectivity. The conversion rate of toluene reached 81% within 20 h. Moreover, CMA-4 also had the highest activity to benzaldehyde, with a yield of 48%. The benzoic acid yield was 15%. The solvent HFIP can partially prevent further oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid [28]. However, as the conversion rate of toluene increases, the amount of benzoic acid produced by the over-oxidation of benzaldehyde also increases. Compared with other CMA-n catalysts, CMA-4 exhibits the best catalytic activity, consistent with its largest specific surface area. The next step was to explore the catalytic oxidation reaction under a high concentration of toluene to explore the possibility of making the CMA-4/NHPI catalytic system industrially viable. The amount of solvent, HFIP, was maintained at 20 mL while increasing the amount of toluene to 3 mL, 6 mL and 10 mL ( Fig. 6). As may be seen from Fig. 6a, when the amount of toluene was 3 mL, the yield of benzoic acid suddenly increased to 10% at 16 h. After 20 h of reaction, the yield of benzaldehyde was 43%, and the yield of benzoic acid was 13%. Interestingly, when the amount of toluene was further increased to 6 mL and 10 mL, the yield of benzoic acid tended to decrease. After 10 mL of toluene was reacted for 20 h, the yield of benzaldehyde was 24%, and the selectivity was 65% (Fig. 6c). The yield of benzoic acid was 3%, which was significantly lower than the yield of benzoic acid obtained using 1 mL (Fig. 5, CMA-4) and 3 mL toluene. This suggests that the presence of a large dosage of toluene may inhibit the formation of benzoic acid from benzaldehyde. In addition, in the high-concentration toluene system, HFIP can partially protect benzaldehyde from over-oxidation to benzoic acid. According to the information in Fig. 6, the HFIP solvent seems to effectively protect the benzaldehyde from forming a large amount of benzoic acid. To better compare the catalytic oxidation performance of the CMA-4 catalyst at different toluene concentrations, Fig. 7 shows the conversion rates of toluene and the corresponding benzaldehyde generation rates. An increase in the concentration of toluene leads to an increase in the conversion rate of toluene and the formation rate of benzaldehyde. In the 10 mL toluene system, the conversion rate of toluene was the highest (5826 μmol g−1 h−1), while the formation rate of benzaldehyde was also the highest (4049 μmol g−1 h−1). To the best of our knowledge, the conversion rate of toluene and the formation rate of benzaldehyde in the CMA-4/NHPI system are significantly higher than those of the currently reported catalyst materials (Fig. S8). Fig. 8 shows the recyclability of CMA-4. The catalytic activity of CMA-4 did not show a significant decline over five recovery cycles. Zhou's group reported that Co-Al oxides prepared by calcining LDHs were active for toluene oxidation [33], and the toluene conversion rate was very low. In the CMA-n/NHPI system, the oxidation of toluene involves transferring a hydrogen atom from the benzyl group to PINO, followed by oxidation of the benzyl group by O2 to obtain benzaldehyde [18,25,28,48]. The primary role of the CMA-n catalysts is to oxidize the hydroxyl groups on NHPI to produce PINO ( Fig. 9) [18,20,25,28,48,49]. An essential function of the HFIP solvent is to combine with benzaldehyde to form a H-bond donor-acceptor relationship, thereby protecting benzaldehyde from over-oxidation to benzoic acid (Fig. 9). Pappo's group demonstrated the formation of strong hydrogen bonds between HFIP and benzaldehyde by auto-oxidation experiments of benzaldehyde and computational studies [28]. According to the computational studies, the benzaldehyde-HFIP system's homolytic CH bond dissociation energies are about 15 kJ mol−1 higher than for pure benzaldehyde [28]. 4 Conclusions TEM images show that the CMA-n catalysts (apart from CMA-5) exhibit a sheet-like structure in keeping with the hydrotalcite layered structure of the CMA-n precursor. The CMA-4/NHIP catalyst system displays high activity and selectivity for the catalytic oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. The high selectivity is attributed to the formation of hydrogen bonds between the HFIP solvent and the generated benzaldehyde, which can effectively prevent over-oxidation to form benzoic acid. In the low-concentration toluene system (1 mL toluene, 20 mL HFIP), the conversion of toluene was 81%, the yield of benzaldehyde was 48%, and the yield of benzoic acid was 15%. In the high-concentration toluene systems (3 mL, 6 mL, 10 mL toluene, 20 mL HFIP), the protection of benzaldehyde by HFIP is still effective. Interestingly, the high-concentration toluene system can not only increase the conversion rate of toluene and the formation rate of benzaldehyde, but also further inhibit the generation of benzoic acid. The conversion rate of toluene and formation rate of benzaldehyde in the 10 mL toluene system was the highest (5826 and 4049 μmol g−1 h−1, respectively). In summary, the results of this study show that the CMA-n/NHIP-HFIP catalytic system may be used for the liquid-phase oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde, thereby breaking the bottleneck of benzaldehyde production relying on a large amount of solvent. coredata.dc:description: The main problems of liquid-phase oxidation of methylarenes to benzaldehydes are that the catalytic reaction rate is slow, benzaldehydes are easily over-oxidized to form benzoic acids, and a large amount of solvent is required. These problems make it difficult to realize the liquid phase catalytic oxidation of methylarenes to benzaldehydes in industrial production. Here, we report the catalytic oxidation of toluene to form benzaldehyde, by using N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) as the radical catalyst, sheet-like Co-Mn-Al oxides (CMA-n) as the redox catalyst, and 1,1,1,3,3,3-hexafluoropropan-2-ol (HFIP) as the solvent. CMA-n/NHPI was found to be highly active in catalyzing the oxidation of toluene to benzaldehyde. The use of HFIP as the solvent prevents the over-oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid. In addition, the reaction proceeded at a high concentration of toluene. The conversion rate of toluene reached 5826 μmol g−1 h−1, and the generation rate of benzaldehyde reached 4049 μmol g−1 h−1.
coredata.dc:title: Application of Co-Mn-Al sheet-like metal oxide catalysts in the liquid phase conversion of toluene to benzaldehyde
